author: Mike Kelly
title: Why Great British Bake Off switch was bigger shock than Brexit
text:
Why Great British Bake Off switch was bigger shock than Brexit 18:30, 17 Sep 2016 The news the popular show is moving from the BBC to Channel 4 has caused massive outrage Shares Get daily news by email Ian West/PA Wire Mel Giedroyc, Sue Perkins, Mary Berry and Paul Hollywood 
Forget Brexit - the most controversial decision this year to date has been the one which will see the Great British Bake Off switch from the BBC to Channel 4. 
Like Brexit, I suspect there are wheels in motion behind the scenes frantically trying to find a way to overturn the move, but it’s not going to happen. 
Judging by the reaction to the news, it seemed for many in the UK that their universe revolved around the axis that is the GBBO, presented by Mel Giedroyc and Sue Perkins and judged by Paul Hollywood and Mary Berry, national treasures one and all. 
And now that axis has shifted, buildings have crumbled and the air has become filled with a despairing wail of ‘why?’ ‘why?’ ‘why?’ 
Put simply, everyone’s over reacted. 
The GBBO is switching to Channel 4 as it was prepared to fork out £25m a year to the independent production which makes it and the Beeb wasn’t. It has to count the pennies more carefully these days and so was only prepared to offer £15m. 
I’m a fan of the show myself and when it makes the switch I’ll carry on watching it. I like Channel 4, however I seem to be in a minority of fans with that view. 
I love Mel and Sue but can’t understand why they announced they were leaving it so soon after the decision was made public. Were their noses put out because they weren’t consulted, or have they got something against Channel 4? Ian West/PA Wire The Breat British Bake Off presenters Mel Giedroyc (left) and Sue Perkins 
The ironic thing is I suspect many of the ‘how very dare they?’ brigade have at some time grumbled about the sprendthrift BBC and were keen to see it tighten its purse strings. 
Now it has agreed to take on the £750m cost of the subsidy for over-75s license fees after pressure from the Tories, it has had to, the result being bye bye to the GBBO . 
Some other popular shows might follow, what with this and the Beeb having to reveal how much it pays to its stars, another Tory brainwave. If only it was so full and frank about who its donors are and how much they hand over. All in good time, no doubt. 
Paul Hollywood has, according to some reports, intimated he will stay on after the Channel 4 move, but no white smoke so far from the Mary Berry hut to indicate what she’ll do. 
Mary is the Tory poster girl of Middle England and might be uncomfortable being on the same station as ‘pinkos’ like Channel 4’s Jon Snow so I suspect she won’t follow Hollywood. 
And if she quits, who will the Tories blame that on? The last Labour government no doubt.
